title: Portrait of Clara Fasano
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Execution Date
notes.content: Stella drew his friend Clara Fasano on numerous occasions, creating casual studies and posed portraits such as this bold, formal image. Her fashionable hat, flowing black veil, and dramatic red lips and scarf clearly place her in the 1940s. The strong outlines of her face and jacket suggest a self-assured, modern woman. One of America’s foremost modernist artists, Stella retained strong ties to his Italian roots as well as to the traditions of the old masters. Even when drawing his friends, he preferred a strict profile view, reminiscent of the early Italian Renaissance tradition.

notes.label: Execution Date
notes.content: Graphic Masters II: Highlights from the Smithsonian American Art Museum, 2009

title: Bush Clover and Birds
data_source: Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum

notes.label: Catalogue Status
notes.content: Research in Progress

notes.label: Description
notes.content: Bush clover (hagi) is a member of the seven flowers or grasses of autumn (aki no nanakusa). This plant is a popular motif typically worn from August to mid-October. It has become a fashionable kimono design since used in a scene from the Tale of Genji. This plant is also associated with being strong. Floating among the bush clover are clouds covered with silhouettes of birds. Silk threads have been added to support the stencil structure.

title: White wig worn by André 3000 of Outkast
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A white wig worn by André 3000 of Outkast during concerts on a 2014 international tour. The custom-made wig is a short style with blunt, choppy tips and long lengths falling in front of the wearer's ears. Synthetic white hairs are attached to a thin strip of woven tape, which is formed into a skullcap using pieces of cream lace. A solid panel of cream lace is attached at the interior front quarter. A rectangular panel of cream synthetic fabric is attached at the interior center back with a length of thin ribbon across the middle of the panel that has lines of stitching forming flat loops in the ribbon. Two (2) cream elastic straps extend one on each side from the center back, each strap has a plastic hook at the end closest to the center back that is attached around the ribbon loops on the fabric panel.

title: Teal blue dress and cropped jacket designed by Ann Lowe
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: Teal blue floral brocade dress (.1) and cropped jacket (.2) designed by Ann Lowe and worn by Florance Colgate Rumbough Trevor.

notes.label: Description
notes.content: The dress (.1) is made from a teal blue silk satin with an all-over brocaded medium-scale design of scattered flowers with leaves and stems in shades of pink, blue, copper, and green. The dress is strapless with a plunging V at the back of the fitted bodice. A self-fabric band is sewn across the front at the natural waist which continues down each proper side of the skirt to the hem. The skirt is nearly flat in the front but is heavily gathered into small pleats at the back. It has a slight train at the center back. Self-fabric pre-tied bows are sewn down the sides of the skirt on top of the self-fabric band, three (3) on each side. Two (2) of these bows are sewn at the center back bodice, one at the top edge and one at the waist. The dress closes at the center back bodice with a zipper and one (1) metal hook-and-eye at the top. Each of the bows snaps onto the proper left side on top of the closed zipper with one (1) metal snap each.

notes.label: Description
notes.content: The interior bodice of the dress is lined with blue silk faille. Boning is sewn between the facing and lining around the bodice. There is a thin band of elastic sewn across the front bodice outlining the breast cups. A wider band of elastic is sewn below the bust line that fastens at the center back with two (2) metal hook-and-eyes. A band of cream ribbon is sewn around the interior waist band that fastens at the center back with two (2) metal hook-and-eyes. Cream fabric hanger straps are sewn at each side of the bodice. There is a metal eye at each front side top edge above each breast, corresponding to a hook in the jacket (.2). The attached petticoat of the skirt is made from the blue silk faille and has a separate interior closure using one (1) metal snap and one (1) metal hook-and-eye, fastening inside underneath the outer zipper closure. The attached faille petticoat is lined in white buckram. The facing fabric of the skirt is lined in cream gauze that is slightly stiff, with this lining sewn into the seams with the facing fabric and separate from the inner petticoat. Circular metal weights covered in the facing fabric are sewn around the interior hem of the skirt. There are no labels in the dress.

notes.label: Description
notes.content: The cropped jacket (.2) is made from the same teal brocaded silk satin as the dress. The bottom of the jacket falls at the bust line and has a shawl collar with short sleeves. It closes at the center front below the bust using two (2) metal hook-and-eyes. A pre-tied self-fabric bow is sewn over the closure, fastening on the proper right with one (1) metal snap. The jacket is lined in the same cream gauze used to line the facing fabric of the skirt on the dress. Short straps made from the blue silk faille used to line the dress bodice with one (1) metal hook on the end are sewn at the front side, fastening to the eye sewn to the interior top edge of the dress bodice above each breast. The proper right strap of the jacket is missing. There are no labels in the jacket.

title: Patent Model for an Ellipsographic Copying Machine
data_source: National Museum of American History

notes.label: Description (Brief)
notes.content: This patent model demonstrates an invention for a carpenter's type-cutter and protractor; the invention was granted patent number 2894. The cutter and protractor was a machine for cutting multiple copies from a single pattern. Typically, it was to be used in making wood type, which could be enlarged or reduced, extended or compressed, thrown into perspective, or turned into "grotesque type of any given fashion from the same plain pattern."

title: Portrait of a Young Man
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: William Page was at the height of his career when he painted this portrait. By 1834 he was fully established in the New York art world as a member of the American Academy, achieving the distinction of board member only one year later. These achievements left him with no shortage of wealthy patrons. Page showed this genteel sitter in his finest clothing, with rosy cheeks and lips framed by fashionably long whiskers.

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Smithsonian American Art Museum, Gift of the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

title: Miss Satterlee
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: Miss Satterlee sat for Charles Bird King in his Washington studio. Her pet golden pheasant grips her forefinger and thumb, its elegant body mirroring the shape of her delicate hand. For a painter of his time, King made a rather daring choice in positioning the bird to call attention to Miss Satterlee’s bosom. Her fashionable clothing, intricate hairstyle, and fair, unblemished skin suggest that she, like her pet, lived a sheltered and protected life.

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Smithsonian American Art Museum, Gift of Albert M. Pitcher, Jr.

title: Green Chinese Jar
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: This painting shows a large pale green urn and a small figure of a Chinese scholar. After the fall of the Qing, China’s last imperial dynasty, hundreds of thousands of porcelains, paintings, and sculptures made their way out of China and into Western hands. A Chinese jar described as “pale green . . . on an ebony standard” was given as a gift at the society wedding of Countess Alice S. Szechenyi and Count Bela Hadik in 1931. Ruth Payne Burgess’s painting reflects the vogue among fashionable ladies of the 1920s for “Oriental” gowns and interiors.

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Smithsonian American Art Museum, Gift of John Gellatly

title: Fort George Island, Florida
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: In 1877, Thomas Moran traveled with his wife to Fort George Island, Florida, and made small studies of the trees and beaches, images that were radically different from his sweeping vistas of Yellowstone. Within twenty years after this painting was created, the balmy coasts of South Carolina, Georgia, and Florida had become fashionable tourist destinations. The hazy blue sky, palm trees, and golden sand suggest a romantic desert island where people could escape their everyday lives.

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Smithsonian American Art Museum, Gift of Neil M. Judd

title: Landscape near Newport, R. I.
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: In 1870, Edward Bannister and his wife moved from Boston to Providence, Rhode Island. The state capital had a rapidly growing immigrant population at that time, and African Americans struggled for job opportunities. Despite these difficult circumstances, Bannister established himself by tapping into the market for pastoral landscape scenes, fashionable among wealthy Providence patrons. Dealer Seth M. Vose popularized these works by importing Barbizon paintings from France to Rhode Island. (Hartigan, Sharing Traditions, 1985)

title: Háh-je-day-ah'-shee, Meeting Birds, a Brave
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: George Catlin painted this image of Meeting Birds, a member of the Ojibwe/Chippewa tribe, either in 1835 at Fort Snelling, a military post in present-day Minnesota, or in 1836 near Sault Ste. Marie. He described Meeting Birds as “a brave, with his war-club in his hand.” Catlin later wrote about Indian weapons: “Their primitive clubs are curiously carved in wood, and fashioned out with some considerable picturesque form and grace; are admirably fitted to the hand, and calculated to deal a deadly blow with the spike of iron or bone which is imbedded in the ball or bulb at the end.” (Catlin, Letters and Notes, vol. 1, no. 29, 1841, reprint 1973, and 1848 Catalogue, Catlin’s Indian Gallery, SAAM online exhibition)

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Smithsonian American Art Museum, Gift of Mrs. Joseph Harrison, Jr.

title: New England Hostess
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: William Gerard Barry painted many members of fashionable society after he arrived in America in 1888. Critics praised the young artist not only for his “rare knack of catching a likeness,” but also for his ability to convey a sitter's spirit (Chicago Daily Tribune,  June 1, 1890). Here, the lady's handsome features and vibrant green sash stand out against the creamy shades of her dress and the wall behind her. Her confident, appraising expression and relaxed arms suggest a woman who was very comfortable in her own skin.

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Smithsonian American Art Museum, Gift of Laura Dreyfus Barney and Natalie Clifford Barney in memory of their mother, Alice Pike Barney

title: The Silver Hand Glass
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: In 1891 a group of women protested several of Kenyon Cox's nude studies at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts annual show. Cox advocated the nude as an artistic subject but was often criticized because his nudes looked too familiar. For example, in this image the woman gazes into a nineteenth-century silver mirror, wears a fashionable pompadour hairstyle, and sits in a turn-of-the-century domestic interior with contemporary wallpaper. Cox based his treatment of the subject on classical and Renaissance models, but he was always mindful of keeping up with the times. He wanted his nudes to have "real flesh and bodily appearance" so they would appeal to modern tastes. (Morgan, Kenyon Cox, 1856-1919: A Life in American Art, 1994)

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Smithsonian American Art Museum, Gift of Joan Armstrong Schmidt

title: Drawing on Door
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: Drawing on Door captures a flirtatious encounter between a young man and woman. The peaceful setting, traditional clothing, and woman's tender skepticism impart a sentimental tone on the painting. Genre paintings that show scenes of everyday life have been a popular subject throughout history. They were especially fashionable around the time of the Industrial Revolution because they presented a romantic view of the past during a time of rapid change.

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Smithsonian American Art Museum, Gift of Laura Dreyfus Barney and Natalie Clifford Barney in memory of their mother, Alice Pike Barney

title: Portrait of Mrs. John Gellatly
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: Edith Rogers was the wife of the art collector and patron John Gellatly, who donated his significant collection of American and European painting and decorative art to the Smithsonian’s National Collection of Fine Arts (now the Smithsonian American Art Museum) in 1929. Edith met John while he was enrolled in art classes, and they married in 1886. Mr. Gellatly was in the insurance and real estate business, and he and his wife were passionate about collecting art. Elizabeth Eleanor Greatorex captured Edith’s youthful beauty and fashionable sophistication in this portrait study, possibly painted during one of her art lessons with Greatorex.

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Smithsonian American Art Museum, Gift of John Gellatly

title: Head of the Queen of Egypt
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: The Metropolitan Museum of Art was still new when Kenyon Cox went there to study art from around the world. Without having to travel abroad, American artists could learn from examples of ancient sculpture in the Met’s collection of plaster casts. Cox copied an Egyptian portrait and, following the fashion for trompe l’oeil, or “fool the eye” painting, he created the illusion of paper tacked onto the sculpture’s base. His poem reads, “O Queen of Egypt with the lovely brow---Taya---thou smiled and to me it seems/The earth has owned before such smile; ‘Twas thou/Visitest Lionardo in his dreams.”

title: Wife of Kee-o-kúk
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: “This woman was the favourite one, (I think) of seven whom he had living, (apparently quite comfortably and peaceably,) in his wigwam, where General Street and I visited him in his village on the Des Moines river. And, although she was the oldest of the ‘lot,’ she seemed to be the favourite one on this occasion---the only one that could be painted; on account, I believe, of her being the mother of his favourite son. Her dress, which was of civilized stuffs, was fashioned and ornamented by herself, and was truly a most splendid affair; the upper part of it being almost literally covered with silver brooches.” Catlin painted this portrait at a Sac and Fox village in 1835. (Catlin, Letters and Notes, vol. 2, no. 56, 1841; reprint 1973)

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Smithsonian American Art Museum, Gift of Mrs. Joseph Harrison, Jr.

title: Mother (Annie Williams Gandy)
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: Annie Williams Gandy, affectionately nicknamed “Mother,” was a close friend of Thomas Eakins and his wife. One critic noted Eakins’s ability to capture an expression in which “mere thinking is portrayed without the aid of gesture or attitude.” (Simpson, “The 1880s,” Thomas Eakins, 2002) Here, Eakins enlists the viewer in an intimate, pensive moment, portraying Annie in a morning coat and braids to suggest that she has just risen from bed. While the subject of women lost in reverie was fashionable at the turn of the twentieth century, most artists chose to idealize their sitters. Eakins, on the other hand, did not disguise their blemishes and “worry lines,” and many people considered his portraits to be unflattering. (Perry, Women on the Verge: The Culture of Neurasthenia in Nineteenth-century America, 2004)

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Smithsonian American Art Museum, Bequest of Mrs. Lucy G. Rodman through her sister Miss Helen W. Gandy

title: Mary Hopkinson
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: Mary Hopkinson was the wife of Dr. John Morgan, chief surgeon of the Continental army and founder of the University of Pennsylvania Medical School. In a letter to his mother-in-law, Morgan praised his wife as “an excellent companion at all times . . . full of spirits.” In this portrait, Mary holds a mandolin, a fashionable instrument for aristocratic ladies. She wears a lavish pink satin gown with a sable collar and pearls that adorn her sleeves and hair. This outfit was not typical dress for colonial women, but was invented by the artist to conjure eighteenth-century European tastes for all things related to the “Orient.” (Reinhardt, “The Work of Fancy and Taste,” Dress, vol. 29, 2002) Benjamin West painted this portrait from a miniature of Mary that her husband brought with him during his visit to London in 1764.

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Smithsonian American Art Museum, George Buchanan Coale Collection

title: The Green Drawing Room of the Earl of Essex at Cassiobury
data_source: Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum

notes.label: Catalogue Status
notes.content: Research in Progress

notes.label: Description
notes.content: This stately drawing room features a fashionable sky-patterned ceiling with a trompe l'oeil of an eagle holding the central chandelier; matching dark green wall covering and curtains; and wood carvings by Grinling Gibbons. Paintings flanking the door are by J. M. W. Turner; the one to the right is titled The Thames at Walton Bridge. On either side of the fireplace, pediments holding bronze statuettes are attributed to Andre Boulle himself, while mounted porcelain vases decorate the tops of Boulle-style cabinets. A table and chais are in the Louis XV style. On the left, there is a woman seated at a piano and on the right, a small dog in the foreground.

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Thaw Collection

title: James Buchanan
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: James Buchanan served many roles before he was elected the fifteenth president of the United States. This portrait was painted after his term as minister to Russia, but he also acted as a representative, senator, and secretary of state. Jacob Eichholtz's painting accurately depicts Buchanan, who often wore black suits and large white cravats. The future president appears composed and confident, but his slightly uneven eyes give him an intimidating stare. The portrait was owned by Buchanan and then given to his niece, Harriet Lane Johnston, who served as his official hostess at the White House during his administration.

notes.label: Luce Object Quote
notes.content: "He was, on the whole, a distinguished and handsome looking man, and his size and fine proportions gave a dignity and commanding air to his personal presence. His manner and bearing had much of the old-fashioned courtly school about it." James Buchanan Henry, quoted in The Works of James Buchanan, ed. John Bassett Moore, 1911, p. 330

title: Muslin Handkerchief
data_source: National Museum of American History
object_type: neckcloth; Neckwear; Accessories Worn on the Body; Female

notes.label: Description
notes.content: The market revolution of the 1700s expanded people’s access to goods from around the globe. American merchants and business owners in the early republic acquired and sold a variety of smaller goods such as tea from China and ceramics from England. Handkerchiefs from India—such as this one made of pink and blue muslin—often appeared in merchants’ ledger accounts. For instance, Ramsay recorded an imported “Sastracundy” handkerchief, the name indicating its Southern Indian origin. As a fashionable and practical accessory, men and women wore the piece of cloth about the neck, tucked into a pocket, or carried in the hand. This Indian handkerchief is made with a pink and blue pattern on white muslin. It has a floral border 2” wide. Floral sprigs overall and a floral medallion details the center.

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Gift of John Brenton Copp

title: Pshán-shaw, Sweet-scented Grass, Twelve-year-old Daughter of Bloody Hand
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: This portrait, according to George Catlin, gives “a very pretty specimen of the dress and fashion of the women in this tribe [the Arikara]. The inner garment, which is like a slip or frock, is entire in one piece, and beautifully ornamented with embroidery and beads, with a row of elks' teeth passing across the breast, and a robe of the young buffalo's skin, tastefully and elaborately embroidered, gracefully thrown over her shoulders, and hanging down to the ground behind her.” Catlin painted fewer women than men, a fact explained by their secondary place in Indian society. As the young daughter of an Arikara chief, however, Sweet-scented Grass possessed status in the tribe and the means to dress in “a robe of the young buffalo’s skin, tastefully and elaborately embroidered” in northern Plains style. Catlin painted this portrait at an Arikara village in 1832. (Catlin, Letters and Notes, vol. 1, no. 25, 1841, reprint 1973; Truettner, The Natural Man Observed, 1979; Gurney and Heyman, eds., George Catlin and His Indian Gallery, 2002)

title: Oó-je-en-á-he-a, Woman Who Lives in a Bear's Den
data_source: Smithsonian American Art Museum

notes.label: Luce Center Label
notes.content: “This extraordinary length of hair amongst the Crows is confined to the men alone; for the women, though all of them with glossy and beautiful hair, and a great profusion of it, are unable to cultivate it to so great length; or else they are not allowed to compete with their lords in a fashion so ornamental (and on which the men so highly pride themselves), and are obliged in many cases to cut it short off.” George Catlin further explained that the “Crow women (and Blackfeet also) are not handsome, and I shall at present say but little of them. They are, like all other Indian women, the slaves of their husbands: being obliged to perform all the domestic duties and drudgeries of the tribe, and not allowed to join in their religious rites or ceremonies, nor in the dance or other amusements . . . The Crow and Blackfeet women, like all others I ever saw in any Indian tribe, divide the hair on the forehead, and paint the separation or crease with vermilion or red earth. For what purpose this little, but universal, custom is observed, I never have been able to learn.” (Catlin, Letters and Notes, vol. 1, no. 8, 1841; reprint 1973)

The green leather case has a blue silk lining. The side seams are torn and the leather is partially abraded. There is a button closure to open the hinged lid.

title: Blue draped turban
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A blue silk dupioni draped turban (a). The exterior of the hat is made from one tube of silk dupioni that is draped around the head, with an interlocking twist knot at the center front. The silk dupioni has tapered edges that are secured at the center back of the hat. There are three hand sewn darts, one at the center back and two at the top of the crown. The drapery across the hat is secured with hemstitching thought the hat which is visible on the interior. The hat is unlabeled and unlined. The hat has a matching hat pin made of metal with a faux pink pearl end (b).

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Collection of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture, Gift of the Black Fashion Museum founded by Lois K. Alexander-Lane

title: Straw hat with multicolored embroidery
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A straw hat with pink, white, and black embroidery. The hat is made from one piece of woven straw. The crown of the hat is rounded and circular. The brim of the hat is upturned at the sides. Numerous areas of the hat are decorated with polypropylene embroidery. A circular patch of satin stitches in pink and white are embroidered on front of the crown slightly offset to the proper left. Black straight stitches surround the satin stitches. Pink and white running stitches circle the base of the crown, these end in a bow at the back of the hat offset to the proper right. Pink couching stitches and chain stitches are sewn at the edge of the brim. The brim at the sides of the hat is folded. The interior of the hat is unlined and contains no label.

title: Navy cap with red pom-pom
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A navy wool hat with a red pom pom. The hat is made of one piece of wool felt blocked into shape. A red cotton yarn pom-pom is adhered to the center top of hat. Two ply cord covered in a silk synthetic, possibly rayon, rests across the brim. Holes containing the ends of the red cord are present on the sides of the hat at the ends of the visor. The cord is knotted at each hole at the hat's interior. The blocked wool felt wraps around the bottom of the visor to encase a wood stiffener. The hat is unlined and has an adhered label at the top of the crown at the hat's interior. The label is made of red silk acetate and reads [DERBY // LOUISVILLE, KY. // IMPORTED // FRENCH BODY // ALL WOOL // WPL 10688 // ADJ].

title: Red skullcap with leaf appliqué
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A red flat skullcap with rhinestones and velvet leaf appliqué. The top of the crown is slightly pointed and tapers downwards as the sides. The body of the hat is made from stiff synthetic net blocked to shape. Decorative leaves cut from velveteen and backed with a non-woven paper adhesive are hand-stitched to hat with large basting stitches. Rhinestones are glued to the leaves. Metal wire is attached to the edge of the hat with machine stitches along the blocked net. A rayon petersham ribbon sweatband and velveteen trim that encases another wire encircles bottom edge of the hat. There are grips attached to each side of the hat made of looped wire covered in red velvet. There are two labels at the center back of the hat; the first reads [Frank R. Jelleff INC. NEW YORK WASHINGTON, D.C.], the second reads [22].

title: Brown hat with strap and net veil
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A brown high crown hat with a brown chin strap and net veil. The upturned edges of the hat have been sewn with a matching brown thread. The hat is composed of brown felt and has a brown net veil adhered to the back. A chin strap made from brown felt hangs from the bottom of the hat. The hat is made of brown felt and has a veil composed of a brown, medium weight, stretchy fishnet material that hangs from the bottom of the hat at the back. A chin strap made from brown felt hangs from the bottom of the hat. A gold beaded decoration, in the shape of an upturned half circle is sewn over the back of the hat, on top of the net veil. The interior of the hat is unlined. There is a brown Petersham ribbon that is stitched along the interior crown. There is a yellow fabric label stitched to the center back interior that reads [22. Mfd under labor standards.]

title: Blue cap with white pom-pom
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A blue wool cap with a white pom-pom. The body of the hat is made from dark blue wool felt. The hat has a circular crown and curves inwards at the sides. There is a white wool pom pom adheared to the top of the crown. The brim at the front of the hat is machine stitched to the crown and is stiffined with possibly paper or plastic. The wool is turned sliglthy inwards at the bottom edge and secured with machine stitching at the inteior. There is a silk synthetic label with scalloped edges and adhered to the top of the crown at the inteior that reads [DERBY LOUISVILLE, KY. IMPORTED FRENCH BODY ALL WOOL WPL 10888 ADJ].

title: Rose print silk covered raffia hat
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A raffia hat with a rose printed fabric covering the crown. The rose printed fabric is cream colored with red roses and green stems. Synthetic green leaves are stitched to the center front, along with a fabric bow made from the rose print material. The interior of the hat is unlined. There is a black Petersham ribbon that is stitched along the interior crown. Black ties made from a Petersham ribbon are stitched to the left and right side of the interior. There is no label.

title: Red hat with two bows
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A blocked fur felt red hat with two bows. The hat is indented at the top of the crown creating a “telescoped” blocked shape. The brim of that hat is blocked to resemble a breton hat brim. There is a viscose satin ribbon where the crown of the hat meets the brim with a bow at the center front and the center back. The bows are secured to the hat with hand stitches. A metal wire is attached to the top of the brim at the hat's interior with a metal aglet. Another metal wire is machine stitched to the bottom raw edge which is then folded to the interior. This wire is covered with a red petersham ribbon sweatband. There is a fabric label stitched to the hat's interior at the center back that reads [A Clemar ORIGINAL by Wesco].

title: Cotton patchwork hat with bow
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A cotton patchwork hat with a bow. The hat has a flat crown that fits closely to the top and the sides of the head. Striped fabric and ribbon in blue, red, orange, green, black, and white is used to make the hat's exterior. A self-fabric bow at the center front is hand-stitched to the hat with blue cotton thread. The bow is made of the same striped fabric and ribbon as the hat. The hat flares slightly at the bottom edges and is pointed on the sides. A synthetic grosgrain ribbon is stitched to the interior at the edge of the hat. A plastic hair comb is secured in place with basting stitches at the center back of the hat's interior. The hat is lined with silk organza and is attached with machine stitches.

title: Yellow velveteen pillbox hat
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A pillbox hat made from a yellow, velveteen material. The hat features a circular, flat crown and slightly curved, upright sides. The front of the hat is slightly shorter than the sides and back. The interior of the hat is lined in a yellow, synthetic material. A red, white, and blue fabric tag stitched to the center back reads [New York. Paris. Mr. John, Classic] A white fabric tag with embroidered pink flowers stitched to the interior right reads [Woodward & Lothrop. Washington, DC.]

title: Hat with yellow and orange flower appliqué
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A brimless hat with yellow and orange flower appliqué. The base of the hat is made of light green synthetic taffeta with six machine stitched darts that meet at the top of the crown. The center back dart transitions into a seam that extends to the edge of the hat. Excess fabric from the dart fold is tacked down with adhesive to the crown forming the base for the flowers. Orange and yellow flowers and dark yellow leaves are glued to the hat's exterior which cover most of the visible surface area of green taffeta. Each flower is made of three to four layers of silk organza, blended silk synthetic and glued to the hat's exterior. A circle of synthetic green velvet is glued to the center of each flower. Sheer dark yellow silk chiffon is used to make long leaf shapes at the sides of hat. The interior of the hat is unlined. The raw edge of the green taffeta is folded, and machine stitched to exterior. Cording possibly made of elastic is encased in the rolled hem at the bottom of the hat.

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Collection of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture, Gift of the Black Fashion Museum founded by Lois K. Alexander-Lane

title: Suede cap with tri-color panels
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A suede cap with brown tri-color panels. This hat is a variation of the newsboy silhouette with a narrow, flat visor and a full crown. The hat's exterior is made of suede in shades of brown and tan. A metal button covered in the darkest shade of brown is tacked to the top of the crown. The crown is made of triangle shaped panels which are machine sewn together and arranged so that a pattern of three shades of brown and tan alternate twice. The hat's visor extends from the center front of the hat and is made with paper stiffener covered in dark brown suede. The inside of the hat is lined with black synthetic faille. A band of bias-cut synthetic twill tape is machine stitched to the bottom edge of the hat's interior. The twill tape is backed with buckram and paper stiffener is sewn behind the twill tape. A yellow woven union label is stitched at the center back.

An orange Petersham ribbon is adhered along the inner circumference of the hat. Black fabric ties are stitched along the interior of the hat. There is tan make up residue on front of the black fabric ties. A yellow fabric tag is stitched over the Petersham ribbon on the center back interior and reads [georgÍ] in black script.

A rayon petersham ribbon is machine stitched to the edge of the hat at the interior. title: Purple pleated hat with three-looped bow
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A high crown, purple and silver hat made from synthetic silk acetate material. The sides of the hat are constructed from knife pleated purple fabric. A triple looped bow is stitched to the top of the hat. The outer fabric of the bow is constructed from purple material, while the inner portion of the bow is made from silver fabric. The knot in the middle of the triple looped bow is made from silver fabric. Synthetic silk lines the interior of the hat. Black elastic cords are hand stitched to the lining at the right and left of the hat. There is no label.

title: Cream hat with feather decoration
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A cream fur felt cloche with feathers. The crown of the hat is round and fits closely to the head. Fur is used to make the body of the hat. The length of the fur is short, resembling alpaca fur in texture. White and brown feathers are placed on the proper left side of the hat along with two decorative twists of the cream fur. The bottom of the hat is upturned at the brim and has a wire along the edge for shaping. The brim of the hat has a split at the center back. Bias-cut silk satin is placed along the underside of where the hat’s brim is folded upwards. A grosgrain ribbon is stitched along the interior circumference. A label is printed on the crown’s interior and reads [Musketeer IMPORTED BODY MADE IN AUSTRIA] in cream script.

title: Black pillbox hat with veil and pom poms
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A black pillbox hat with a net veil and pom poms. The body of the hat is made of two separate pieces of black wool felt with the top of the crown stitched along the sides of the crown. Three circular black plastic buttons are sewn to the center front of the hat. Self-fabric fringe synthetic pom poms are attached to the proper left and right sides of the hat. Nylon net is tacked down to the top of the crown at the center back. The hat band at the back of the hat is made of metal wire encased in black wool felt. It is attached to the hat along the sides of the crown. The interior of the hat has black buckram and a petersham ribbon is machine and hand stitched along the inner circumference.

title: Blue hat with burgundy velvet ribbon
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A blue fur felt cloche with a burgundy velvet ribbon and bow. The top of the hat has a flat rounded crown. The hat is made of long fur, possibly angora mohair. The hatband is made of a red velvet ribbon. A large bow made of the same ribbon is stitched to the center front of the hat. The brim of the hat sits close to the face and slopes downwards. The hat’s brim is shorter at the back. The edge of the hat’s brim is turned under to encase a metal wire used for shaping. At the hat’s interior a cotton rayon blended grosgrain ribbon is machine stitched at bottom edge. There is an illegible marking on the hat's interior at the top of the crown.

title: Brown and cream striped day dress from the Civil War era
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A brown and cream striped cotton day dress from the Civil War era. The dress has a fitted collarless bodice that buttons at the center front with six (6) black vulcanized rubber buttons marked on the reverse "I.R.C. Co. / 1851. / GOODYEAR". The fitted full-length sleeves have a detail at the wrist with the fabric sewn on the bias. Self-piping is sewn at the gathered waistband, which is more heavily gathered in the back. The skirt is full with a wide hem that falls at or below the ankles. The dress is both machine and hand sewn. The bodice and sleeves are lined with a plain cotton muslin. The skirt is not lined. There is one inset pocket at the proper right hip, with the pocket made from plain cotton muslin.

The hat band is made of a thick black rayon grosgrain ribbon. A bow made of the same ribbon is tacked to the center front of the hat with black thread. The edges of the brim are rolled upwards. title: Brown velvet hat with leaves and bow
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A brown velvet hat with a bow and leaves. The exterior of the hat is made of brown silk velvet cut on the bias. The crown of the hat is rounded and loosely fitted to the head. At the sides of the crown the brown velvet is decoratively gathered and stitched. Decorative stitches in orange thread in swirling patterns are seen on the front, left, and right sides of the hat. Seven appliqued leaves applied to the brim are made of silk and silk velvet with gold metallic thread. The backside of the leaves are covered with cotton fabric. An appliqued bow made of dark yellow silk grosgrain ribbon is stitched to the center back of the hat with metallic thread. The brim of the hat is longer at the sides and tapers inwards at the center front and back. Wire is applied to the edge of the brim. The hat is lined with brown silk on the bias and cording is placed at the interior where the crown of the hat meets the brim.

title: Orange damask hat with elephant print
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: An orange damask hat with an elephant print and gold metallic detail. The body of the hat is made of four pieces of cotton damask machine stitched together; one for the top of the crown, the sides of the crown, and two for the brim. The hat has a tall crown with a flat top. There is a seam on the side of the crown visible at the center back. Seams are visable on the brim at the center front and center back. Decorative gold metallic thread is machine stitched around the top of the crown, base of the crown and at two rows at the edge of the brim. Black polyester fusible interfacing lines the inside of the hat providing structure.

title: Pink hat with two-tone panels
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A wool felt pink hat with two-tone panels. The panels are light and dark pink and are made from a shiny, satiny material. The panels are sewn in an overlapping pattern that extends along the sides of the hat from the front to the back. A decorative piece of pink felt is sewn over a light pink panel of fabric on the back left side of the hat. The interior of the hat is unlined. There is a light pink Petersham ribbon stitched to the interior crown. A yellow fabric tag stitched to the center back over the Petersham ribbon reads [Woodward & Lothrop, Washington, DC]. A smaller fabric tag to the right of the brand label reads [22 ½] in dark brown text.

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Collection of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture, Gift of the Black Fashion Museum founded by Lois K. Alexander-Lane

title: Printed turban style hat
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A printed turban style hat with draping. The crown of the hat is flat and circular. The exterior of the hat is made of blue, yellow, and green abstract printed silk. The silk is draped across the hat at the center front. The drapery across the hat is secured with hand stitches. There are two decorative loops of green velvet hand stitched to the center front of the hat. The interior of the hat is made from buckram blocked in shape. The hat is lined in a light green synthetic silk brocade and secured to the edge of the hat with hand stitches. There is a hidden wire 1.25” from hat’s bottom edge. Braided silver metallic thread is hand stitched to the bottom edge of the hat. Under the metallic thread a green velvet band is stitched to the interior, this is partially visible from the outside. There is a label stitched to the inside of the hat at the center back that reads [AN original BY SOPHIE].

title: Red straw skullcap with matching ruffle flower
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: Red straw skullcap with a large ruffle flower, made from the same material, on the proper right side. A peach-colored synthetic material with red stitches in a diamond pattern cover the interior of the hat and a red Petersham ribbon lines the interior crown. A white fabric tag reading [Bené Original] is stitched over the red Petersham ribbon at the center back of the hat.

credits.label: Credit Line

title: Grey balloon sleeve dress designed by Arthur McGee
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: Grey wool dress designed by Arthur McGee. The A-line dress is knee-length with a mock turtleneck and full-length balloon sleeves. There are two (2) patch pockets, one at each front side hip. The dress closes at the center back with a zipper and one (1) hook into a thread loop. Gussets are sewn at each underarm. It is not lined. Thin elastic is sewn inside the hem of each sleeve to create the balloon effect. A cream fabric label with black woven text is sewn at the proper right back side opening near the top that reads "Arthur McGee".

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Collection of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture, Gift of the Black Fashion Museum founded by Lois K. Alexander-Lane

title: Gray wool skirt by Arthur McGee
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A gray, wool woven, A-lined skirt made by Arthur McGee. The skirt is made from two bias cut panels, sewn in a spiral structure. One panel begins at the proper left front and extends down to the proper right, ending at the proper left at the bottom hem. The second panel extends from the proper right and circles around to the left. The bottom hem is two inches. The hem is folded under, and hand stitched in place with catch stitches in white thread. The inside of the skirt is unlined and there is no label. There is seam binding sewn into the waistband made from synthetic dark gray material and a metal hook closure that hooks into looped thread. A black metal zipper is machine stitched into the center back of the skirt with black thread. The zipper length is 6.25". There is a simple seam in the center front that has been pressed open. Its edges are not surged. The seams attaching the panels are pressed, simple seams with surged edges.

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Collection of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture, Gift of the Black Fashion Museum founded by Lois K. Alexander-Lane

title: Grey tweed hooded cape designed by Arthur McGee
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A wool hooded Twill weave cape with a grey herringbone pattern designed by Arthur McGee. The hood is made from two pieces and sewn together at the center back with a welt seam. It’s gathered along the bottom and sewn into the body of the cape. The body of the cape is composed of two circular pieces seamed together at the center back. There are no arm holes. There are four dark brown plastic buttons handstitched to the proper right and four corresponding buttonholes on the proper left. There is a ½ inch to 5/8 inch seam along the bottom of the cape. The back of the cape has a vent at the center bottom. There is no label and the inside of the cape is unlined

title: Grey, blue, and maize-colored cotton striped dress designed by Willi Smith
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: Grey, blue, and maize-colored cotton striped dress designed by Willi Smith for WilliWear Limited.

notes.label: Description
notes.content: The dress is a straight cut shift dress with a scoop neck and short shirt sleeves. There is a breast pocket on the proper left side, with angled bottom corners. The fabric is a heather grey cotton with vertical navy blue and yellow stripes in varying widths.

notes.label: Description
notes.content: There are two tags sewn into the back of the collar on the inside. The top tag is white and reads [Willi Smith] in red and [WiLLiWear] in grey. The tag below is white and reads [M / MADE IN INDIA / 100% COTTON / HAND WASH / SEPARATELY / IN COLD WATER] in black.

title: Yellow woven Breton hat
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A yellow woven Breton hat with a yellow ribbon. The base of the hat is made of woven synthetic raffia and is blocked to shape. The top of the crown is flat, and the sides of the crown fit closely to the head. The hat has a deep brim that wraps upwards completely covering the sides of the crown from view. Synthetic bouclé yarn is glued to the center of each synthetic raffia ribbon at crown and inner brim. A metal milliner's wire runs along the edge of the brim and is hidden by a yellow rayon petersham ribbon that is attached with machine and hand stitching. A yellow rayon petersham ribbon is also machine stitched to the hat's inner circumference as a sweatband. There is a white woven label stitched to the center back of the hat along the sweatband that reads [Jelleff's] in black text. A union label is hidden underneath this.

title: Pink velveteen hat with purple feathers
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A pink velveteen hat with purple feathers and a rose. The base of the hat is made of buckram covered in pink silk synthetic blended velveteen. The crown and the brim are separate and are attached with hand stitches. The crown of the hat is flat and short. Purple feathers are adhered to hat at the base of the crown. There is a pink rose at the center front of the hat at the base of the crown made of synthetic velveteen. The green sepal at the base of the flower is made of polyester plain weave that is hidden from view by the feathers. The hat is lined with black sheer polyester organza at the crown and the pink velveteen continues to the underbrim. Metal wire is placed at the edge of the brim, it is hidden under the pink velveteen.

title: Orange straw hat with raffia hat band
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: An orange straw hat with a raffia hatband. The body of the hat is made of one piece of woven straw. The top of the crown is rounded and circular. The hat band is made of orange petersham rayon ribbon wrapped around cream colored raffia. This is tied in a knot at the back of the hat with the edges of the raffia and ribbon falling onto the brim. The brim of the hat is wide and slopes slightly downwards. The inside of the hat is unlined. There is a label on the inside of the hat at the center back that reads [Betmar], along with a union label underneath.

title: Pink draped turban with fringe
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A pink silk dupion draped turban with fringe. The base of the hat is made of double-layered nylon blocked into shape with silk dupion draped and hand-stitched to the exterior. Cotton organdie is used to back the silk dupion and is attached with hand-stitching. Fringe constructed from self-fabric silk dupion is at the top of the crown. A strip of buckram is placed at hat's interior at the top of the crown. The silk dupion is folded and tacked to the interior with basting stitches. A pink rayon petersham ribbon is hand stitched to the inside of the hat. A label is sewn to the center back of the hat along the petersham ribbon that reads [Macy’s Little Shop].

title: Two tone straw hat with star underbrim
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A straw hat with a natural toned crown and black brim. There is a black ribbon stitched where the natural toned crown meets the black brim. The interior of the hat is unlined. Natural toned straw in the shape of a star is stitched to the underside of the black brim. Both a white and a black Petersham ribbon are sewn along the interior crown. A white, fabric tag that reads [Bené Original] is stitched to the interior center back of the crown.

credits.label: Credit Line
credits.content: Collection of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture, Gift of the Black Fashion Museum founded by Lois K. Alexander-Lane

title: Cream quilted bucket hat with bow
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A cream quilted bucket hat with a bow. The hat is made of three pieces of cream silk dupioni, one piece for the top of the crown, one for the sides of the crown, and another for the brim. All these pieces of fabric are machine stitched to one another. The top of the crown is flat and circular. The silk used for the sides of the crown is cut on the bias. A seam is visible at the side of the crown at the center back. There is a large bow adhered to the center front of the hat made of a cream rayon cotton blended petersham ribbon. The brim of the hat is short and is made of silk also cut on the bias. Buckram is placed on the inside of the brim. The inside of the hat is lined with cream acetate. There is a cream colored petersham rayon ribbon sweatband machine stitched to the edge of the crown. Discoloration in the shape of a rectangle at the center back of the petersham ribbon suggests that a tag was previous adhered to the interior. A union label is adhered to the inside of the hat hidden under the sweatband.

title: Grey fur hat
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A grey fur brimless hat with a black chin strap. The exterior of the hat is made of two pelts of on-skin fur, possibly from mink or rabbit. A seam extends from the center front to the center back where the pelts have been joined. The inside of the hat is lined with grey silk faille. There is a cream synthetic brocade ribbon with pink, yellow, and green floral patterning machine stitched to the edge of the hat's interior. The interior ribbon secures the raw edge of the fur which is folded inwards. Two strands of elastane cord covered in white synthetic fabric are hand stitched to the center back of the hat's interior. A strap of elastane cord covered in black synthetic fabric is attached at sides of the hat. The cord has been fed through small holes in the inner band and secured with metal barbs at either end. There is a fabric label with pinked edges at the center back of the hat that reads [BACHRACH’S ® WASHINGTON D.C.].

title: White hat with rhinestone bow
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A white satin hat with a rhinestone bow (a). The hat is blocked in a pillbox shape variation and is created using two pieces of viscose, one for the crown and one for the side of the hat. The crown is short and fits closely to the head. The sides of the hat are slightly extended and come to a point by the ears. Twenty-one glass rhinestones joined in a metal setting in the shape of a bow are tacked to the center front of the hat. The raw edges of the satin viscose rayon are folded under at the crown and bottom edge of the hat. The interior is lined with white buckram and a synthetic plain weave lining is adhered over buckram at the crown. A black petersham rayon ribbon inner band is attached with two rows of machine stitching to the interior. A strip of buckram is folded behind the petersham ribbon and machine stitched to ribbon and hat. The hat has a matching metal hat pin with a faux white pearl (b).

title: Black breton hat with veil
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A black breton hat with a net veil. The exterior of the hat is constructed of black bias-cut velvet. The crown is short and fits closely to the head. The upward facing brim is made of black synthetic satin that covers stiff interfacing. There is a small looped tab at the center back of the brim to conceal a diagonal seam. Nylon net is attached where the upper brim satin interfacing and velvet meet. Decorative small V-shaped details are woven into the net. The hat's interior is made of two layers of buckram and is fully lined with a sheer black polyester organza. A paper covered metal wire is attached along the edge of the brim and sewn with zig zag machine stitching. A black petersham ribbon sweatband is machine stitched at bottom edge. A fabric label is located at interior center back that reads [Mr. Rickie ORIGINAL MADE EXPRESSLY FOR Jelleff’s].

title: Yellow draped turban style hat
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A yellow draped turban style hat. Synthetic twill weave fabric is draped and folded on the hat's exterior. These folds are hand tacked into place. The draped fabric is tied into a bow at the center back of the hat. The base of the hat is constructed of stiffened interfacing. The hat is lined with two panels of machine stitched synthetic faille. A fabric label is stitched to the center back of the hat's interior and reads [Mr. Rickie // ORIGINAL // MADE EXPRESSLY FOR JELLEFF’S]. A union label is sewn behind the maker label.

title: Red hat with beaded flower and orange hat band
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A red hat with a beaded flower and an orange hat band. The base of the hat is made of buckram. The brim and the crown are made of separate pieces that are hand stitched together. The crown of the hat is short and rounded, it is made of a red synthetic velveteen. A pleated orange rayon cotton blended petersham ribbon is tacked to the base of the crown. The ribbon is decoratively looped and folded at the center back of the hat with two strands that extend off the of the brim that are cut at an angle. The top of the brim is made of synthetic faille. The edge and the underside of the brim are made of the same red velveteen as the crown of the hat. A flower made of folded red rayon petersham ribbon is tacked to the center front of the hat at the edge of the brim. Faux plastic pearls and glass sea beads are stitched to the front of the flower. On the inside of the hat the crown is lined with red synthetic faille. Two metal wire grips wrapped in orange rayon petersham rayon ribbon are inserted at the base of the crown at the interior.

title: Blue faux fur cap
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A blue faux fur cap with a knit hatband and visor. The crown of the hat is constructed from four triangular panels of faux fur that are machine-stitched together. A self-fabric pom-pom is hand-stitched to the top of the crown. A cotton jersey knit hat band is machine stitched to the crown and is backed with a non-woven interfacing. The visor at the center front of the hat is covered in cotton jersey knit and shaped with a stiffener possibly cardboard. The inside of the crown is backed with a synthetic knit, possibly acrylic or polyester. A petersham nylon ribbon is machine stitched along the hat's inner circumference. There is a woven label underneath the petersham ribbon that reads [UNION MADE // KH 7273 // IN U.S.A 6].

title: Flower petal pillbox hat with netting
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A pillbox hat (a) with purple flower petal decorations with netting. The top of the crown is flat with the sides of the hat extending straight down. The base of the crown is made from purple buckram. The hat's exterior is adorned with purple and green gradient silk velvet petals attached with adhesive. A nylon net veil is tacked to the center of the crown and extends off the sides of the hat. Chenille pom poms are added across the veil along with iridescent rhinestones at the center front. There is a metal wire covered with purple velvet ribbon that surrounds the edge of the hat at the interior. A white label is sewn along the metal wire and reads [UNION MADE GO 047149 IN U.S.A.] with a [UNITED HATTERS CAP & MILLINERY W’KRS – INT. UNION] seal in black script. The paired hat pins are made of metal with a plastic lavender teardrop shape at the end of one and a pink sphere other (b and c).

title: Black pillbox hat with round interlocking panels
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A black pillbox hat with abstracted round interlocking panels. The hat is made of a buckram understructure while the exterior is covered in a black silk velvet. The hat is made of three separate pieces of fabric for the top of the crown, sides of the crown, and the brim which are all machine stitched together. The brim folds upwards the proper left side of the hat and continues to the back of the hat. On the proper right side, the two ends of the brim curve upwards and interlock creating a structured abstract decorative element. The edges of the hat are bound with black petersham ribbon. The inside of the hat is lined with a silk synthetic taffeta. There is a black petersham ribbon sweatband sewn at the interior. Three stitches of white cotton thread form a star on the sweatband which marks the center front of the hat. A silk satin label is placed on the inside of the hat at the center back which reads [Macy’s Little Shop].

title: Yellow pillbox hat with bow
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A yellow pillbox hat with a matching bow. The top of the crown is flat and circular. The hat is made from yellow velveteen set on the bias and has a buckram interfacing. There is an inverted yellow velvet bow hand sewn to the center front of the hat. There are seven rows of quilting stitches that run the length of the velveteen used to make the bow. The inside of the hat is lined with machine stitched cream silk taffeta. A yellow petersham rayon ribbon is machine stitched to the inner edge of the hat. There is a metal wire at the hat's inner seam hidden by the rayon ribbon. A label is adhered on the center back of the hat that reads [PARIS Gibbé Hat NEW YORK] in red script.

title: Black wool cloche
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: An asymmetrical black wool cloche. The hat is constructed of a single piece of blocked wool felt. The top of the hat is rounded and fits closely to the head. The wool felt is draped and creased at the center front of the hat continuing to the proper right side. The hat is longer on the proper right side as it continues down the face ending in a rounded point. A black petersham ribbon and metal wire covered in paper are stitched to edge of the hat at the interior. title: Red had with double rolled brim
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A red wool felt hat with double rolled brim. The hat is made of blocked fur felt. The top of the crown is indented at the center, fitting close to the head. At the sides of the crown there is a band of gathering stitches that pulls the hat inwards at the center. These stitches do not continue to the back of the hat. The hat has a double rolled brim that is separated in the center by a machine stitch. The two parts of the brim cross over one another in the front. There is a stamped label at the inside of the hat at the top of the crown that reads [Neumann-Endler, INC. Fair Field Felts 100% WOOL]. title: Black derby hat with cream bow

title: White hat with striped trims and black bow
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A white brimmed hat with black and white striped trims and a black bow. The hat is made of white polyvinyl chloride with black and white striped acetate trim set on the bias. The trim is on hat’s crown and brim and glued to the polyvinyl chloride. A double looped large black bow made of crin with plastic rhinestones at the bow’s center is tacked to the base of the crown. title: Straw hat with brown ribbon
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A tan blocked woven straw hat with brown ribbon (a). The hat is made of two separate pieces of woven straw, one is used for the crown and the other for the main body. The hat’s crown is short and rounded. The crown of the hat is machine stitched to the main body of the hat. These stitches are concealed by a brown rayon petersham ribbon hat band. The hat band is hand stitched to the base of the crown. The edges of the hat band meet in the center back of the hat and extend two inches. title: Green beret with black ribbon

notes.label: Description
notes.content: An olive-green beret with a black velveteen ribbon. The body of the hat is made from one piece of blocked wool felt. The top of the crown is flat and circular. The sides of the crown taper slightly inwards at the bottom. A black velveteen ribbon hatband is attached with adhesive. A bow with one loop and two tails is adhered along the velveteen ribbon on the proper right side. The edge of the hat is slightly folded to the interior and secured with machine stitching. A rayon petersham ribbon sweatband is machine stitched to the interior. A black rayon label is placed at the top of the crown at the interior that reads [madcaps®]. Underneath text printed in white reads [WPL 4384 MADE IN U.S.A. 100% WOOL].

title: Purple pancake-style hat with puckered fabric and rhinestones
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description

The interior of the hat is lined with a black synthetic fabric. A black Petersham ribbon lines the interior crown and a black, elastic chin strap is attached under the Petersham ribbon. A yellow fabric tag with a red border is stitched to the center back interior of the hat. The fabric tag reads [Mertize Millinery. Detroit, Michigan] in red font. The hat has an accompanying price tag reading [$50.00] printed in black on off-white paper.

title: Pleated beret with rhinestones
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

The interior of the hat is unlined. An orange Petersham ribbon is stitched along the length of the interior crown. A gold fabric tag stitched over the Petersham ribbon at the center back seam reads [Woodward & Lothrop, Washington]. title: Blue derby hat with feathers and flowers
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: Blue derby hat with feathers and flowers. The dark cadet blue hat has a rounded crown at the top, and a small brim with a rounded edge. There is a navy blue Petersham ribbon going around the base of the hat, above the brim. At the front of the hat are several small bunches of faux flowers in gradient shades of dark blue and white with olive green leaves. Extending from the flower bunches are white, blue, and grey feathers. In the interior is a navy blue Petersham ribbon and stamped gold letters reading [WPL 4384 (?). Made in U.S.A. 100% Wool] There is a white manufacturer’s label with jagged edges and dark blue text reading [Custom Made By / Bené].

title: Blue and yellow hat with silk flowers
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A beret style hat with blue, yellow and white silk flowers and an elastic strap (a). The base of the crown is made of white rayon faille covered in cream silk crepe. Flowers made of silk organza and possibly a silk synthetic blend are hand tacked to the surface of the crown, hiding the base fabric. The flowers are layered over each other, with the silk synthetic blend pieces on the bottom and the lighter organza pieces on top. Pistils made of synthetic fiber and white coating have been pulled through the center of the flowers, their ends are secured with floral tape to create a stem. The flowers are blue, white, and yellow, though substantial dye bleed has occurred, and the colors have blended. The hat band is made of green straw braid and is machine stitched to the crown. The hat is fully lined in bias-cut rayon faille with a small scale pink rose print. The lining is hand stitched along the hat band with green cotton thread. Black elastic cord with metal barbs is secured through two holes in the lining on the sides of the hat. The hat has a detached white woven fabric label (b) that reads [FASHIONED BY // Ronnie] in black text with an orange border.

credits.label: Credit Line

title: Lavender tweed swing coat designed by Arthur McGee
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: Lavender wool tweed swing coat designed by Arthur McGee. The fabric has multi-colored wool woven flecks. The coat has a spread collar, full-length flared sleeves, and falls just below the knee. It closes at the center front neck with one (1) snap and one (1) large round metal decorative brooch-like button with a purple rhinestone at the center. The rest of the front center opening does not fasten. There is one (1) horizontal pocket sewn at the proper left front waist. Pleats are sewn at each underarm to create additional flare at the sides. The back is made extra full with a deep box pleat sewn at the center back just below the shoulders.

notes.label: Description
notes.content: The coat is fully lined in green silk satin. The body has an additional lining between the facing and the satin made from green wool. The linings of the body are not seamed to the interior bottom hem, but are instead left loose with a turned hem finish. The wool lining is slightly shorter than the satin lining. There are no labels.

title: Yellow jumpsuit designed by Willi Smith
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: Yellow jumpsuit designed by Willi Smith for WilliWear Limited.

notes.label: Description
notes.content: The jumpsuit has a v-neck, a notched lapel collar, and short sleeves and is made of yellow cotton fabric. There is a breast pocket on the proper left side with rounded bottom corners. There are six yellow plastic buttons going down the center on the proper left side, starting at the base of the v-neck and going down to where the pant legs start. There is a hem around the bottoms of the sleeves and around the bottoms of the pant legs. The jumpsuit has a cinched waist with two belt loops on the back and a slash pocket on either hip.

notes.label: Description
notes.content: There are three white tags sewn into the back of the collar on the inside. The small tag on the proper right side reads [7/8] in black. The center tag is large and reads [WILLI WEAR LTD / Designed by Willi Smith] in black. In between the two lines of text there is a cartoon drawing of a man's face in profile. The man has short hair, glasses, and a collared shirt. The tag on the proper left side reads [100% COTTON / MADE IN / MAURITIUS / HAND WASH] in black.

notes.label: Description

There are three grey buttons going down the front on the proper left side, starting at the bottom of the v-neck and going to where the pant legs start. title: Purple hat with rhinestone star
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A draped purple brimless hat (a). The exterior of the hat is made of purple acetate. Two raised circle self-fabric bands are sewn to the top of the crown. The hat is gathered with machine-stitching where the raised circle meets the hat’s body. The purple acetate is also gathered at the bottom edge of the hat. The hat curves in an inverted "V" shape at the center font and back. The inside of the hat is lined in a silver and black metallic silk acetate novelty weave. Wire is placed at the bottom edge of the hat and the edge of the fabric is folded to the interior. A petersham rayon ribbon sweatband is machine stitched to the interior edge of the hat. Bias cut buckram is placed at the edge of the hat hidden underneath the sweatband. A star shaped broach (b) made of rhinestones set in metal is meant to pin to the center front of the hat. The hat also has a matching hat pin (c) with a lavender plastic pin head.

title: Brown bowler with hat band
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A brown wool felt bowler with a hat band. The body of the hat is made of brown wool felt. The top of the crown is rounded and tapers straight downwards. Hidden paper stiffener is placed on the bottom two thirds of the crown. There is a brown rayon petersham ribbon hat band that is adhered to the base of the crown. A bow is placed along the hat band at the proper left side. The edge of the hat's brim is upturned and finished with brown rayon ribbon. The interior of the hat is lined with a golden colored synthetic satin. There is a sweatband made of black synthetic silk satin that is adhered to the interior at the base of the crown. Buckram is placed behind the sweatband. The inside of the hat is stamped with a label at the top of the crown that reads [QUALITÉ SUPÉRIEURS, Lucienda Brafant et Frére, MARQUEE DEPOSEE, CHAPELLERIE EXCLUSIVE, PARIS PLUS HAUTES DISTINCTIONS]. There is a paper tag on the outside of the hat attached at the edge of the bow on the hatband that reads [THANK YOU! "WE KNOW YOU WILL ENJOY YOUR BEAUTIFUL NEW HAT."] on one side. On the other side [160 AMISH] is stamped in blue ink and 500 and 1000 are written in blue ink.

title: Black cap with ribbon and veil
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A black hat with a bow and decorative net veil. The body of the hat is made of black blocked fur felt. The top of the crown is flat and is rounded at the sides. An inverted "V" shaped cut out is placed at the center back of the hat. A black silk satin ribbon bow is handstitched to the center back of the hat at the top of the cut out. Another bow is sewn at the bottom of the cut out. This bow is tacked on proper left and right back of the cut out which creates the illusion that the ribbon serves as an adjustable drawstring. A silk net veil is tacked to the center back of the hat at the bottom bow and to the sides of the cut out. The fur felt of the hat's exterior is folded at the edge to the interior. A petersham rayon ribbon sweatband is handstitched overtop of the folded felt securing it to the interior. There is a black elastic strap secured to the sides of the hat behind the petersham ribbon with tacking stitches. Two large basting stitches in white thread mark center front of the hat on sweatband. A fabric label is sewn to the interior at the top of the crown that reads [E.M. Swaim NEW YORK]. Another label is stamped underneath this that reads [Merrimac SUPERIOR FUR FELT].

title: Hat with pink, blue, and white flowers
data_source: National Museum of African American History and Culture

notes.label: Description
notes.content: A derby-style hat made from synthetic straw. There are pink, blue, and white faded synthetic flowers and leaves stitched along the outer brim. The inside of the hat is lined with a gold net material. There is a white Petersham ribbon stitched along the inner crown of the hat. A white fabric tag is stitched over the Petersham ribbon on the center back and reads [An Original by Dajon. New York.] in black and red text. To the slight left is another white fabric tag with pink embroidered flowers that reads [Woodward & Lothrop. Washington, DC] in black text.
